column38: They expect us to entertain them.
column45: Students are being led to believe that they must just clock the right amount of time being entertained in order to get a credential for the class. Having punched that time clock, they can move on. This is how they were taught in experiences prior to coming here and the view carries over. We are thus trending away from effective education. Things that are difficult, and stretch young minds, become things which are avoided by students or punished if faculty try them. Campus tolerates this trend away from effective and challenging goals since there is a perverse view that highly popular teaching practices (as measured by the CourseEvalUM system, an instrument that no scientist would use as basis for drawing any conclusion) somehow translate into good recruiting opportunities and ratings. This becomes even more perverse since promotions and (at least when we had them) raises were based in great part on measuring the wrong things.

column45: Generally, grading is the biggest issue in my course. Because I teach English 101, and the content of the course IS the writing, rather than the subject they're researching and writing about, many students find it difficult to accept what they consider to be harsh grading. I call this a misconception because students generally enter the class with a different idea of what an 'A' paper looks. Issues of organization, clarity, development, and style may not have been of primary importance in, say, a history course.     This misconception about grading generally leads to a misconception about the writing process as well -- that writing a good paper begins when you sit down to fill the white space, rather than when you form your topic ideas and purpose, gather evidence through research, or outline your approach. This misconception leads to a lot of last minute writing.    Both of these points are central to the course purpose, and students generally have a better understanding upon completion.

column38: Give good grades
column45: Conceptual understanding is the most important. But most of the time, they fail to use the conceptual understanding to problem soliving, which is used to measure the student learning outcomes. Many students who are lacking of problem solving skills do poorly in exams and they always complain about the course.  Also, students expect that instructors must respond to their email questions on weekends and at nights. If the exam is easy, then some students say the course is not intellectually challenging and if the exam is hard, students say exam is too long and unfair. Whatever instructors do to make a fair measure of student learnings, it is often impossible to make students happy because many of mondern college students want good grades with minimal efforts. Also, most of the students are 'spectator students' - they just watch an instructor talking and writing and showing and they don't use their hand to take notes. After the class is over, many students seem to leave the classroom with very little left in their memory. Quite obviously, these students do very poorly in the test.

column45: It depends on the course.  In STEM courses, students believe that memorization will help them earn a higher grade on exams and, subsequently, in the course.  This is a misconception.  While some memorization is required, a higher level of understanding is essential in order to do well on exams and in the courses.  Another misconception that students have is that the material in course A is separate from that in course B, when in actuality, the material builds upon itself.

column45: I think that students have misconceptions about grades.  I have encountered students who feel that grades are arbitrary and negotiable.  This especially true for large classes where there are many different sections taught by many different TAs.  It is common for students to feel that their TA grades harder than any other.  This is discouraging to me because it makes it less likely for students to take ownership of their mistakes and work to earn a better grade.

column38: answer questions on ELMS
column45: 1) Despite being told this is not the case, students continue to feel that a good grade is based solely on memorization of lecture material. Conceptual study questions that connect ideas across lectures or from other required foundational classes are usually ignored or met with hostility and students perform poorly on these kinds of exam questions. 2) Despite being told this is not the case, students also appear to feel that is something is stated in lecture but not written on the powerpoint they are not responsible for it. This is exacerbated by poor class attendance. 3) Many students, when confronted with a concept from lecture they don't understand, will forego looking in their textbook or researching online for an answer and instead email the TA to basically have us do this for them. I do not mind helping students develop a more complete understanding of the subject material, but the wording of these requests often reveals the expectation that the TA is a personal tutor available on demand because this is easier than the student studying themselves.

column8: College of Arts and Humanities
column46: I begin each semester asking students (by way of notecards) what their expectations are, and what they would like to come away with (eg, by way of knowledge and skills) by the end of the semester.  I ask them why there are there.  I think, too, there should be a clear distinction between expectations on the part of students and the ways a teacher may challenge, extend, add to, or even be surprising about those expectations.  (For most, I also imagine question 7 is difficult to address for a variety of reasons.)

column45: They are more linear (read memorization) oriented, and it's a challenge for them to grasp that I want them to think critically and conceptually beyond the specifics.
column46: Students rarely take notes (except for the best ones), which is troubling on a number of levels. I'm not sure how to rework my concerns to fit this survey, but there is a definite mind set that I suspect comes from no child left behind -- and from the evaluation based on tests that permeates K-12 (and increasingly higher education).

column45: Students seem surprised at the level of work (it should be easier), that they must read analytically and critically (why should they have to submit papers on the readings), that they are expected to use the library (the instructor should post all readings as pdf files on ELMS), and that are responsible for their own learning (the instructor should present only the information needed for the test).
